statement:
If $(X,\mathfrak{M},\mu)$ is any measure space and $1\le p,q\le \infty$
are then, for $f\in L^p$, the following linear function can be defined
$$\begin{aligned}
&\Phi_f\colon L^q\rightarrow\mathbb{C},\\
&g\mapsto\Phi_f(g)\equiv\int fg\,d\mu.\end{aligned}$$ The shows that
this gives a well defined and bounded linear map. Its operator norm is
given by
$$\Vert\Phi_f\Vert=\left\{\Vert fg\Vert_1:g\in L^q, \Vert g\Vert_q=1\right\}.$$
The following theorem shows that the operator norm of $\Phi_f$ is equal
to the $L^p$-norm of $f$.

Let $(X,\mathfrak{M},\mu)$ be a $\sigma$-finite measure space and $p,q$
be Hölder conjugates. Then, any measurable function
$f\colon X\rightarrow\mathbb{C}$ has $L^p$-norm $$\label{eq:1}
\Vert f\Vert_p=\sup\left\{\Vert fg\Vert_1: g\in L^q, \Vert g\Vert_q=1\right\}.$$
Furthermore, if either $p<\infty$ and $\Vert f\Vert_p<\infty$ or $p=1$
then $\mu$ is not required to be $\sigma$-finite.

Note that the $\sigma$-finite condition is required, except in the cases
mentioned. For example, if $\mu$ is the measure satisfying
$\mu(A)=\infty$ for every nonempty set $A$, then $L^p(\mu)=\{0\}$ for
$p<\infty$ and it is easily checked that equality (\[eq:1\]) fails
whenever $f=1$ and $p>1$.
